A simple question related to Graph coloring could be:

Suppose you have a graph with 5 vertices, how many colors are required to color the vertices such that no two adjacent vertices have the same color?
message_2:
The number of colors required to color a graph such that no two adjacent vertices have the same color depends on the structure of the graph and its maximum degree. In the worst-case scenario, the graph with 5 vertices could be a complete graph, meaning that every vertex is connected to every other vertex.

In a complete graph with 5 vertices, the maximum degree of any vertex is 4 (since it is connected to the other 4 vertices). According to the graph coloring theorem, the number of colors required to color a graph is at most one more than the maximum degree of its vertices. Therefore, in this case, a maximum of 5 colors would be required to color the graph such that no two adjacent vertices have the same color.

However, if the graph is not complete and has a lower maximum degree, fewer colors may be required.
